Description: Lid sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl with part of flange; white slip; interior reserved; exterior black-figure decoration consisting of sphinx to left (head, forelegs and rump missing; added red on hair, wing, underbelly and hind leg); incised rosette with red centre as filling ornament; at rim, two lines and band of short rays; on edge of rim, blobs.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Stage 1 of Group D of the Sphinx and Lion Style. Although the imagery is lively, the execution of the figures is loose and careless. The rosette on vases of Stage 1 appears casual.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 314, no. 1342, pl. 174)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 83, no. 36, pl. V) (Incorrectly labelled G.120.15)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2125) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
